item.title: Obama’s Vow on Chemical Weapons Puts Him in Tough Spot
item.description: President Obama surprised aides last year when he declared that the use of chemical weapons in Syria would cross a “red line.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER, MARK LANDLER, DAVID E. SANGER and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: The Official Facebook page of President Bashar Assad, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Syria’s leader, Bashar al-Assad, right, surrounded by bodyguards on Saturday in Damascus for the inauguration of a statue dedicated to university “martyrs” who were killed in the country’s civil war, in an image released on his official Facebook page.

item.title: Life in North Korean Complex: A Glimmer of Hope
item.description: The suspension of operations at a joint North and South Korean factory complex has dimmed optimism that the two nations were trying to find common ground.
item.dc:creator: By SU-HYUN LEE and MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kwak Kyung-dock, center, who was a manager at the Kaesong complex, on Thursday at a factory in Bucheon, near Seoul.

item.title: Satirical Song Blocked in Pakistan, but No Reason Is Given
item.description: No official explanation has been given for the apparent ban on the song, which critics have praised for its sharp humor.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Saudis Allow Sports for Some Schoolgirls
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s official news agency says private girls’ schools are now allowed to hold sports activities in the kingdom, “according to the rules of Shariah.”
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Israel Targeted Iranian Missiles in Syria Attack
item.description: Experts said that Israel was taking a calculated risk that limited strikes would provoke only a limited response.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD, MICHAEL R. GORDON and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Twice in four months Israel has sought to disrupt the pipeline of weapons to Hezbollah.

item.title: In Lean Years After Boom, Spain’s Graft Laid Bare
item.description: At a time when Spain, Italy, Greece and Portugal are imposing deficit-cutting austerity plans on their citizens, revelations of widespread political corruption are stoking bitter resentment.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor María Soledad Aured de Torres of La Muela, Spain, with a portrait of the town’s former mayor, María Victoria Pinilla, who is facing charges over what officials call shady land deals.

item.title: Karzai Said He Was Assured of Cash Deliveries by C.I.A.
item.description: The C.I.A. money, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan told reporters, was “an easy source of petty cash,” and he suggested that some of it was used to pay off warlords and power brokers.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: The Afghan leader Hamid Karzai told reporters Saturday that money delivered by the C.I.A. was “an easy source of petty cash.”

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 4
item.description: Pressure on Merkel; new star of Iraqi politics; JP Morgan Chase under scrutiny; and Robert Diamond after the Libor scandal.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel, center, in Berlin last week. Germany's economy is expected to grow modestly this year, a potential source of voter discontent in September's parliamentary elections.

item.title: British M.P. Is Questioned in Rape Inquiry
item.description: Nigel Evans, a deputy speaker in the House of Commons, was being questioned about accusations of attacks on other men.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: Tech Firms Take Lead in Lobbying on Immigration
item.description: Silicon Valley companies and their executives, who want to hire foreign-born engineers, are waging a sophisticated lobbying campaign in support of an immigration overhaul.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC LIPTON and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, at lectern, with other senators who worked on an immigration overhaul now under consideration.

item.title: 8 Soldiers Killed in Afghanistan
item.description: Eight soldiers from the American-led military coalition were killed in Afghanistan: five by a roadside bomb, two by an Afghan soldier who shot his trainers and one by small-arms fire.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Off the Shelf: ‘Alchemists’ Looks at Central Bankers’ Handling of Crisis
item.description: In a new book, Neil Irwin details the tribulations of three central bank leaders in averting economic collapse during the financial crisis.
item.dc:creator: By FRED ANDREWS

item.title: News Analysis: In Latin America, U.S. Focus Shifts From Drug War to Economy
item.description: Conceding leadership of the drug fight to Mexico hews to a guiding principle of President Obama’s foreign policy, in which American supremacy is played down, at least publicly.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:description: President Obama and President Laura Chinchilla of Costa Rica on Saturday in San Jose, Costa Rica.

item.title: At Least 30 Killed in Ethnic Clashes in Nigeria
item.description: Members of the Jukun ethnic group were marching through the town of Wukari, on their way to a funeral, when an argument broke out with local Hausa and Fulani youths.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Far-Right Groups Protest World Jewish Congress in Budapest
item.description: Leaders of a far-right Hungarian political party accused Israelis of plotting to buy up large parts of Hungary.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Freedom Still Eludes the Press, Despite the Arab Spring
item.description: As the United Nations marked World Press Freedom Day, a survey ranked the Middle East at the bottom of an international score card of media freedom. Syria, where at least 23 reporters and 58 citizen-journalists have been killed since March 15, 2011, was unsurprisingly the most perilous place for journalists.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Bassem Youssef, a popular television host in Egypt, entering the state prosecutor's office in Cairo, March 31, after being accused of insulting Islam and the country's leader.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Welcome to Erbil, Tourism Boom Town
item.description: Iraqi Kurdistan is something of an island of stability in a sea of trouble — so much so that the chief city of the non-Arab region has been named next year’s Capital of Arab Tourism.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: The citadel at Erbil, Iraq. The city has been chosen to be the Arab Capital of Tourism for 2014.

item.title: Plans to Harness China’s Nu River Threaten a Region
item.description: The Chinese government revived plans to build a series of hydropower dams on the upper reaches of the free-flowing Nu River, one of Asia’s wildest waterways.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ke Shouyi, 47, a farmer in the Lisu ethnic group, prodded his cow to plow the remote rural area near the Nu River in China’s Yunnan Province.

item.title: Chinese River’s Fate May Reshape a Region
item.description: Those who treasure the Nu River in Bingzhongluo, China, say the construction of proposed dams would alter what guidebooks call the Grand Canyon of the East.

item.title: Year Into Hollande Presidency, ‘a Sense of Drift’
item.description: François Hollande is seen as pleasant, uncharismatic and unauthoritative by many who supported him for president a year ago. Opinion polls say only a quarter of the French view him favorably.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: UKIP in Britain Gains in Popular Support
item.description: The once-derided United Kingdom Independence Party won about a quarter of all votes cast in local elections across England, surprising detractors and calling attention to its policy demands.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS

item.title: 2 Bodies Found at Crash of Military Tanker in Kyrgyzstan
item.description: The bodies were found, a government spokesman said, after firefighters put out a fire at the crash site in Kyrgyzstan.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
item.description: A round-up of news from across India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: India Ink: Pakistani Prisoner Beaten Up in Indian Jail
item.description: India-Pakistan relations strained by the death of an inmate in Pakistan and the injury of a Pakistani inmate in India.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Activists burning Pakistani flags in New Delhi on Friday. They were protesting the death of Sarabjit Singh, an Indian prisoner who died Wednesday, after being beaten up by fellow inmates at a jail in Lahore, Pakistan.

item.title: The Lede: Investigation Suggests American Journalist Missing in Syria Is ‘Likely’ Held by Government
item.description: James Foley, an American journalist who has been missing in Syria, “was most likely abducted by a pro-regime militia group and subsequently turned over to Syrian government forces,” according to GlobalPost, the news site for which he was a freelance correspondent.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK
item.media:description: James Foley, an American journalist, has been missing in Syria since November.
